questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable

options.label: C
options.text: Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels

options.label: D
options.text: Point B to D is refractory period

questions.correct_answer: D. Point B to D is refractory period
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.
  • • AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.
  • • AT POINT 1
  • • AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.
  • • AT POINT 2 -
  • • AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.
  • • AT POINT 3
  • • AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.
  • • AT POINT 4 -
  • • Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.
  • • Point 2 to 4
  • • The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B : Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C : Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.
  • • Option C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phases of an action potential -
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential. Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point A : Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • ➤ Point A
  • ➤ Point B : Marks the threshold potential.
  • ➤ Point B
  • ➤ Point C : Represents the peak of the action potential.
  • ➤ Point C
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase Point E : Hyperpolarization phase Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Point D : Repolarization phase
  • ➤ Point D
  • ➤ Point E : Hyperpolarization phase
  • ➤ Point E
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • ➤ Absolute refractory period
  • ➤ Relative refractory period from around point C to D
  • ➤ Relative refractory period

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024) Kidney Liver Spleen Lung
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.
  • • In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 3 and 4 : While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.
  • • 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of hypertension is being evaluated for kidney function. His blood pressure has been fluctuating significantly over the past few months, ranging from 150/90 mm Hg to 170/100 mm Hg. Despite these variations in blood pressure, his kidney function tests remain stable, and his glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is within normal limits. The nephrologist explains that the kidneys have an intrinsic ability to maintain a constant GFR despite changes in systemic blood pressure. According to the myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, what triggers the contraction of afferent arterioles?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased stretch of the blood vessel walls

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased sodium chloride concentration at the macula densa

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased stretch of the blood vessel walls
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, increased arterial pressure leads to the stretching of the walls of the afferent arterioles. This stretch triggers a reflexive response where smooth muscle cells in the arteriole walls contract, mediated by the influx of calcium ions into the cells. This contraction reduces the diameter of the afferent arterioles, increasing vascular resistance, which helps normalize blood flow and maintain a stable glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This autoregulatory response ensures that GFR remains relatively constant despite fluctuations in systemic blood pressure, protecting the kidney from damage due to high pressure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. High levels of circulating catecholamines While catecholamines can influence renal blood flow, they are not directly involved in the myogenic response. Catecholamines primarily affect systemic blood pressure and can indirectly affect kidney function but are not part of the intrinsic autoregulation of renal arterioles.
  • • Option B. High levels of circulating catecholamines
  • • Option C. Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated in response to low blood pressure or low sodium delivery to the kidneys. Although RAAS plays a crucial role in regulating blood pressure and sodium balance, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response of the afferent arterioles.
  • • Option C. Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
  • • Option D. Decreased sodium chloride concentration at the macula densa This is related to the tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) mechanism, not the myogenic response. TGF adjusts the GFR in response to changes in sodium chloride concentration detected at the macula densa, affecting afferent arteriole tone differently than the myogenic mechanism.
  • • Option D. Decreased sodium chloride concentration at the macula densa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation is triggered by the stretch of afferent arteriolar walls due to increased arterial pressure, leading to smooth muscle contraction and vasoconstriction to stabilize renal blood flow and GFR. This response helps the kidney maintain constant filtration rates despite fluctuations in systemic blood pressure, distinguishing it from other mechanisms like the renin-angiotensin system and tubuloglomerular feedback.

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side

options.label: B
options.text: Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.
  • • The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways
  • • first order neurons
  • • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata. Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.
  • • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above)
  • • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.
  • • Signals from the lower limb (below T6)
  • • The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.
  • • second order neuron
  • • Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.
  • • third order neuron
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side : Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.
  • • Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side
  • • Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side : Incorrect for the same reason as above.
  • • Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
  • • Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side : Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.
  • • Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a severe motor vehicle accident. He presents with significant blood loss and multiple fractures. In the first 24 hours, his vital signs stabilize after resuscitation, After a few days in the intensive care unit, his condition improves with increased body temperature, these changes are part of the body’s physiological response to trauma. Which statement about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow phases in response to trauma is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The ebb phase is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate and oxygen consumption.

options.label: B
options.text: The flow phase involves increased catabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, and immune system activation.

options.label: C
options.text: The ebb phase activates the hepatic acute-phase response and innate immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: The flow phase occurs after resuscitation and is associated with a hypermetabolic state.

questions.correct_answer: C. The ebb phase activates the hepatic acute-phase response and innate immune system.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cuthbertson’s concept of the metabolic response to trauma involves two distinct phases: the ebb phase and the flow phase. The ebb phase occurs immediately after injury and is characterized by hypometabolism, including decreased metabolic rate, reduced oxygen consumption, decreased body temperature, and vasoconstriction aimed at conserving blood volume. This phase does not activate the hepatic acute-phase response or the immune system. In contrast, the flow phase follows after resuscitation and is marked by hypermetabolism, increased catabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, and activation of the immune system and hepatic acute-phase response, which are essential for tissue repair and defense against infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. The ebb phase is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate and oxygen consumption. This statement is correct. The ebb phase reflects the body’s initial response to trauma, characterized by a reduction in metabolic activity to conserve energy and stabilize the patient.
  • • Option A. The ebb phase is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate and oxygen consumption.
  • • Option B. The flow phase involves increased catabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, and immune system activation. This statement is correct. The flow phase is the hypermetabolic state following the ebb phase, characterized by high energy demands, catabolism, and immune activation, crucial for healing and recovery.
  • • Option B. The flow phase involves increased catabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, and immune system activation.
  • • Option D. The flow phase occurs after resuscitation and is associated with a hypermetabolic state. This statement is correct. The flow phase begins after the patient is stabilized and is marked by increased metabolic turnover and heightened physiological activity to support recovery.
  • • Option D. The flow phase occurs after resuscitation and is associated with a hypermetabolic state.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cuthbertson’s metabolic response to trauma consists of the ebb phase, marked by hypometabolism, and the flow phase, characterized by hypermetabolism, increased catabolism, and activation of the immune response. The ebb phase conserves energy immediately post-injury, while the flow phase supports healing and repair through heightened metabolic and immune activity

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities.   • • Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.
  • • In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.
  • • Option A. Microglia.
  • • Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.
  • • Option C.
  • • Astrocytes.
  • • Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ependymal cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

questions.text: In the provided electron micrograph of a sarcomere, which area corresponds to the label “E”? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The label "E" in the electron micrograph points to a section known as the I-band. The I-band is the lighter area of the sarcomere that primarily consists of actin filaments and is known for its isotropic properties, which means it appears lighter under polarized light. It is flanked by the Z-lines and extends between the edges of A-bands from adjacent sarcomeres. The I-band's size varies with muscle contraction, decreasing as the muscle contracts due to the sliding filament mechanism where actin filaments slide towards the center of the sarcomere.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option a (A-band) is incorrect because the A-band includes the entire length of the myosin filaments, whether overlapping with actin or not, and appears darker in micrographs. Option c (M-band) and option d (H-zone) are also incorrect. The M-band is the middle of the A-band where myosin filaments are linked, and the H-zone is the central part of the A-band where no actin filaments overlap, neither of which corresponds to the area labeled "E".
  • • Option a (A-band) is incorrect because the A-band includes the entire length of the myosin filaments, whether overlapping with actin or not, and appears darker in micrographs.
  • • Option a (A-band)
  • • Option c (M-band) and option d (H-zone) are also incorrect. The M-band is the middle of the A-band where myosin filaments are linked, and the H-zone is the central part of the A-band where no actin filaments overlap, neither of which corresponds to the area labeled "E".
  • • Option c (M-band) and option d (H-zone)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The I-band is a key component of the sarcomere, characterized by its lighter appearance due to the presence of actin filaments and its role in muscle contraction dynamics.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents to the clinic for evaluation. During the consultation, the physician discusses the case with the interns regarding how the kidneys maintain stable glomerular filtration rate (GFR) despite changes in blood pressure, a process known as renal autoregulation. Which of the following mechanisms does NOT play a role in renal autoregulation?
questions.correct_answer: D. Neural regulation via sympathetic nerves
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Renal autoregulation is crucial for maintaining a stable GFR and renal blood flow despite variations in blood pressure. This autoregulation relies mainly on the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms. The myogenic response involves the inherent ability of the vascular smooth muscle cells in the afferent arterioles to contract when stretched by increased blood pressure, thereby regulating blood flow. Tubuloglomerular feedback, on the other hand, involves the macula densa cells sensing changes in sodium chloride concentration in the distal tubule, which then modulates afferent arteriolar tone to maintain GFR. Although prostaglandins play a supporting role by dilating arterioles under certain conditions, the sympathetic nervous system primarily influences blood pressure on a broader systemic level and does not directly mediate the fine-tuned autoregulatory processes of the kidneys.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Myogenic response The myogenic response is fundamental to renal autoregulation as it allows the afferent arterioles to respond directly to changes in blood pressure, thereby ensuring a consistent renal blood flow and GFR.
  • • Option A. Myogenic response
  • • Option B. Tubuloglomerular feedback Tubuloglomerular feedback is essential for renal autoregulation, with the macula densa detecting changes in sodium concentration and adjusting arteriolar resistance to stabilize GFR.
  • • Option B. Tubuloglomerular feedback
  • • Option C. Prostaglandin release Prostaglandins can influence renal blood flow by promoting vasodilation, particularly in response to stimuli like angiotensin II or sympathetic activation. They help protect the kidneys during stress but are not the primary regulators of autoregulation.
  • • Option C. Prostaglandin release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal autoregulation maintains a stable glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback, allowing the kidneys to function independently of systemic blood pressure variations. While factors like prostaglandins can modulate renal blood flow, the sympathetic nervous system does not directly control the autoregulatory mechanisms of the kidneys, highlighting the independence of these intrinsic processes.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.
  • • This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation : Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep : Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep
  • • Option D. After running for 1 hour : Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

questions.text: Which of the following does not exhibit a countercurrent mechanism? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The countercurrent mechanism involves the exchange or transfer of heat, substances, or ions between fluids moving in opposite directions and is typically used to create concentration gradients or conserve heat. This mechanism is not present in the eye, as the eye's primary functions involve light reception and processing, which do not require countercurrent exchange systems. The eye relies more on direct blood flow for nourishment and waste removal, differing fundamentally from the countercurrent processes observed in other listed organs.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option a (Kidney) is incorrect to exclude, as the kidney uses a countercurrent mechanism in the loop of Henle and vasa recta to concentrate urine and conserve water. Option b (Testes) also employs a countercurrent heat exchange system between the arteries and veins in the spermatic cord to maintain optimal temperature for spermatogenesis. Option d (Intestine) utilizes countercurrent blood flow in the villi to efficiently exchange nutrients and gases between arterioles and venules.
  • • Option a (Kidney) is incorrect to exclude, as the kidney uses a countercurrent mechanism in the loop of Henle and vasa recta to concentrate urine and conserve water.
  • • Option a (Kidney)
  • • Option b (Testes) also employs a countercurrent heat exchange system between the arteries and veins in the spermatic cord to maintain optimal temperature for spermatogenesis.
  • • Option b (Testes)
  • • Option d (Intestine) utilizes countercurrent blood flow in the villi to efficiently exchange nutrients and gases between arterioles and venules.
  • • Option d (Intestine)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The countercurrent mechanism is notably absent in the eye, an organ primarily focused on visual processing rather than the transfer or exchange of substances through opposing fluid movements.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development?

options.label: A
options.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

options.label: B
options.text: Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body

options.label: C
options.text: Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct

options.label: D
options.text: Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.correct_answer: A. At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body : This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.
  • • Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body
  • • Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct : This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.
  • • Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct
  • • Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia : This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.
  • • Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of: ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Elastin fibres

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.
  • • The ventral portions of the laminae of nearby vertebrae are connected by a network of ligaments called the Ligament flava. They make up a portion of the posterior surface of the spinal canal and primarily consist of elastic tissue. Because it contains a lot of elastin, it can be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm. The ligamentum flava helps with extension back to the anatomical position by helping to prevent laminae separation during flexion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type 1 collagen: Collagen is the primary structural protein, among the different types of collagen, Type 1 collagen is the most abundant. It's found in many tissues including skin, tendons, internal organs, and the organic part of bones. Its primary function is to provide tensile strength to these tissues. It forms strong fibers and is responsible for the strength of the tissue. However, while present in many areas of the body, Type 1 collagen is not the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.
  • • Option A. Type 1 collagen:
  • • Option B. Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in cartilaginous tissues. Its main function is to provide resistance against intermittent pressure, making it ideal for cartilaginous structures like the intervertebral discs, hyaline cartilage, and the vitreous humor of the eye. Given that ligamentum flavum is not a cartilaginous structure, Type 2 collagen is not its predominant component.
  • • Option B. Type 2 collagen:
  • • Option C. Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers are a type of fiber in connective tissue composed of Type 3 collagen. These fibers form a mesh-like framework in various organs such as the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. They provide a supportive framework for these and other organs. While they are present in various parts of the body, they are not the main component of the ligamentum flavum.
  • • Option C. Reticular fibers:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ligamentum flavum, which connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae, contains a high concentration of elastin fibers, which allows the ligament to stretch during spine flexion and then return to its original shape when the spine is extended.
  • ➤ This characteristic helps maintain the stability and alignment of the vertebral column. Thus, among the given options, elastin fibers are the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: A patient with a rare genetic disorder affecting ion channel function undergoes an electrophysiological assessment to determine the resting membrane potential (RMP) of their neurons. The electrophysiologist measures the equilibrium potentials of ions X and Y, finding X = -50 mV and Y = -30 mV. Given that the RMP is maintained without net electrogenic transfer, what is the equilibrium potential of ion Z?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition of no net electrogenic transfer at the resting membrane potential (RMP) suggests that the sum of the equilibrium potentials of ions X, Y, and Z must be zero. This means the ions are balanced in such a way that their individual electrochemical gradients cancel each other out, maintaining a stable RMP. Given that the equilibrium potentials of X and Y are -50 mV and -30 mV, respectively, the equation to balance these ions is:
  • • X + Y + Z = 0
  • • Substituting the known values:
  • • −50 + (−30) + Z = 0
  • • Z = 80 mV
  • • Therefore, the equilibrium potential of ion Z is 80 mV.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When there is no net electrogenic transfer at the resting membrane potential, the sum of the equilibrium potentials of permeable ions must equal zero. Calculating each ion’s contribution allows understanding of how changes in ion concentrations or permeability can alter the RMP, emphasizing the importance of ionic balance in maintaining cellular homeostasis.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.
  • • Types of Gallstones :
  • • Types of Gallstones
  • • Cholesterol Stones : These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones. Pigment Stones : Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders. Mixed Stones : These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.
  • • Cholesterol Stones : These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • • Cholesterol Stones
  • • Pigment Stones : Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • • Pigment Stones
  • • Mixed Stones : These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.
  • • Mixed Stones
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.
  • • Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate:
  • • Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.
  • • Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate:
  • • Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.
  • • Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

options.label: A
options.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given

options.label: D
options.text: Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.correct_answer: D. Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The management of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy involves several key steps to ensure effective treatment and prevent complications:
  • • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring. Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy. Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (≥50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration. Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.

  • • Option D
  • • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours , not 72 hours. Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days , not just 5 days.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics: Correct. Hospitalization, urine and blood cultures, and starting antibiotics are all appropriate steps in managing acute pyelonephritis.
  • • Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics:
  • • Option B. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Correct. Switching to oral antibiotics is appropriate once the patient is afebrile.
  • • Option B.
  • • Oral antibiotics once afebrile:
  • • Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given: Correct. Maintaining a urine output of > 50 mL/h and using intravenous crystalloids are standard practices to manage hydration and ensure adequate renal function.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discharge from the hospital should be considered once the patient is afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics should be continued for 7 to 10 days in cases of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.
  • • Complete Mole: Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity. Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either: One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY. Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY. Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment. Partial Mole: Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum. Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.
  • • Complete Mole: Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity. Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either: One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY. Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY. Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • • Complete Mole:
  • • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity. Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either: One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY. Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY. Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
  • • Ultrasound Finding:
  • • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either: One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY. Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
  • • Genetics:
  • • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY. Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
  • • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
  • • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
  • • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • • Clinical Management:
  • • Partial Mole: Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum. Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.
  • • Partial Mole:
  • • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum. Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.
  • • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.

  • • Clinical Appearance:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.
  • • Option A. Blighted ovum:
  • • Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.
  • • Option B. Missed abortion:
  • • Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.
  • • Option C. Ectopic pregnancy:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mondor’s Disease

  • ➤ The clinical presentation of Mondor's disease includes pain, tenderness, and redness over the affected area, along with a palpable cord-like structure that corresponds to the thrombosed vein. The diagnosis of Mondor's disease is made by physical examination. Treatment for Mondor's disease includes restriction of arm movements, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), warm compresses, and compression garments to alleviate pain and inflammation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tolvaptan causes increased free water clearance by blocking V2 receptors, leading to symptoms of dehydration such as dry mouth and increased thirst. This is a direct result of its mechanism as a V2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department following a severe head injury sustained in a fall. On examination, he is unresponsive, but his vital signs are stable, and imaging reveals a large intracranial hemorrhage involving the cerebral hemispheres. The neurological team notes that his condition is consistent with decorticate rigidity. Which statement accurately describes decorticate rigidity?

options.label: A
options.text: Decorticate rigidity involves flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs.

options.label: B
options.text: Decorticate rigidity involves complete relaxation of all muscles due to brainstem injury.

options.label: C
options.text: Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flaccid paralysis of all four limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: Decorticate rigidity is the result of increased inhibition from the basal ganglia.

questions.correct_answer: A. Decorticate rigidity involves flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Decorticate rigidity, often seen in patients with damage above the brainstem, such as cerebral hemisphere lesions, is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs at the elbows and extension of the lower limbs. This posturing results from the disruption of the corticospinal tract while sparing the brainstem pathways that facilitate flexor muscle activity in the arms and extensor muscle activity in the legs. Decorticate rigidity typically occurs due to intracranial hemorrhage, brain injury, tumors, or abscesses affecting the cerebral cortex or descending pathways, leading to loss of inhibitory control over the spinal reflexes that regulate posture.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Decorticate rigidity involves complete relaxation of all muscles due to brainstem injury. This statement is incorrect as decorticate rigidity involves abnormal posturing with flexion and extension patterns, not muscle relaxation. Brainstem injury often leads to decerebrate rigidity rather than decorticate rigidity.
  • • Option B. Decorticate rigidity involves complete relaxation of all muscles due to brainstem injury.
  • • Option C. Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flaccid paralysis of all four limbs. Flaccid paralysis indicates a complete loss of muscle tone, which is not seen in decorticate rigidity. Instead, decorticate rigidity involves specific abnormal flexor and extensor postures due to upper brain dysfunction.
  • • Option C. Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flaccid paralysis of all four limbs.
  • • Option D. Decorticate rigidity is the result of increased inhibition from the basal ganglia. The basal ganglia are involved in movement control, but decorticate rigidity is specifically related to damage affecting the corticospinal tract and the loss of cortical inhibitory input, not an increase in inhibition from the basal ganglia.
  • • Option D. Decorticate rigidity is the result of increased inhibition from the basal ganglia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decorticate rigidity is a condition characterized by abnormal posturing with flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs due to damage above the brainstem, such as from intracranial hemorrhage or brain injury. This pattern results from the disruption of corticospinal tracts while preserving brainstem control of postural reflexes. Recognizing the specific postural patterns associated with decorticate and decerebrate rigidity is essential for localizing neurological damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.
